questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following structures does otosclerosis affect?
questions.explanation:
Otosclerosis affects the otic capsule. The otic capsule is the dense bony labyrinth of the inner ear that surrounds the cochlea, the 
vestibule, and the semicircular canals. In otosclerosis, one or more foci of irregularly laid spongy 
bone replace part of the normally dense bone. The inner ear is divided into: • The membranous labyrinth is also called the otic labyrinth. It is filled with endolymph. • The bony labyrinth, which is also called the otic capsule. • Periotic labyrinth, which is the space between the bony and membranous labyrinth and is filled 
with perilymph.

questions.question: Question 2: Which layer of the otic capsule is affected in otosclerosis?
questions.explanation:
Otosclerosis affects the enchondral layer of the otic capsule. Within the enchondral layer, there are sometimes islands of unossified cartilage rests that later 
give rise to otosclerosis. The otic capsule is made of 3 layers: • Endosteal: Innermost • Enchondral: Middle layer derived from cartilage that ossifies • Periosteal: Outermost layer

questions.question: Question 3: What is the most common site of origin of otosclerosis?
questions.explanation:
The most common site of origin of otosclerosis is the fissula ante fenestram lying in front of the 
oval window. It is seen in the stapedial type of otosclerosis. Types of otosclerosis : • Stapedial 161 
Sold by @itachibot • Cochlear • Histological. Stapedial otosclerosis is the most common type of otosclerosis.

questions.question:
Question 4: What is the type of otosclerotic focus when the disease process involves the entire footplate 
except for the annular ligament?
questions.explanation:
The otosclerotic focus is biscuit type when the disease process involves the entire footplate except 
for the annular ligament. The otosclerotic foci in the stapedial type of otosclerosis can be of various types: • Anterior focus - involving only the fissula ante fenestrum • Posterior focus- involving only the fissula post fenestrum • Circumferential - affects the margin of the footplate only (annular ligament alone) • Biscuit type - affects the entire footplate except for the annular ligament • Obliterative- affects the entire footplate & its annular ligament.

questions.question:
Question 5: You are an OBGYN resident and your patient is one of your staff nurses. She is a primigravida 
who has just been diagnosed with otosclerosis and wants to know its inheritance pattern. 
Which of the following is the inheritance pattern for otosclerosis?
questions.explanation:
Otosclerosis has an autosomal dominant type of inheritance. About 50% of the cases of otosclerosis have a positive family history while the rest are sporadic. 
Genetic studies reveal that it is an autosomal dominant trait with incomplete penetrance and 
variable expressivity. 162 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: For research on pharmacological treatment in otosclerosis, a researcher wanted to set the age 
limit of the study to the most common age group when the hearing loss usually manifests. 
Which of the following will be a suitable set?
questions.explanation:
The most common age group when the hearing loss in otosclerosis usually manifests is 20-30 
years of age. It is rare before 10 and after 40 years.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is a false statement regarding otosclerosis?

options.a: Females are affected twice as often as males.
options.b: Stapedotomy should be avoided in children.
options.c: HRCT shows double ring sign in stapedial otosclerosis.
options.d: It may be associated with measles.

questions.explanation:
HRCT shows the double-ring sign in cochlear otosclerosis, not in the stapedial type. Otosclerosis affects females twice as often as males. But in India, otosclerosis seems to 
predominate in males. Stapedotomy is contraindicated in children because recurrent eustachian tube dysfunction is 
common in them. This can displace the prosthesis or cause acute otitis media. Measles RNA has been found in otosclerotic foci implicating its possible role in pathogenesis.

questions.question:
Question 8: Which of the following hearing defects is not seen in otosclerosis? 154 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Presbyacusis is not seen in otosclerosis. The following hearing defects are seen in otosclerosis: • Painless progressive bilateral conductive hearing loss most commonly. • Sensorineural hearing loss may be seen in cochlear type of otosclerosis. • Paracusis willisii: Patient hears better in noisy surroundings as other people raise their voice to 
be heard.

questions.question:
Question 9: In a stapedectomy specimen of a patient with otosclerosis, a pathologist noted that a few 
areas of the otic capsule appeared more basophilic than normal. What is this appearance 
called?
questions.explanation:
The blue mantle sign of Manasseh is a histopathological finding seen in otosclerosis. On histopathological examination of an otosclerotic foci, the osteoblasts and osteoclasts lie in an 
abundance of cement substance, which stains blue with hematoxylin and eosin stain. Option B - Blue dot sign is seen in the torsion of the testicular appendage. Blue cement sign and islets in ocean sign do not exist.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 30-year-old Caucasian woman came with a history of progressive hearing impairment 
which improves in a noisy environment. Tuning fork tests revealed a conductive hearing loss 
in both ears. The otoscopic finding is given in the image below. What is the most probable 
diagnosis among the given options?
questions.explanation:
The given image is of a normal tympanic membrane. There is bilateral conductive deafness, 
paracusis willisi and, a normal tympanic membrane which suggest a diagnosis of otosclerosis with 
matured focus. 163 
Sold by @itachibot Paracusis willisi - Patient hears better in noisy surroundings as other people raise their voice to be 
heard. The tympanic membrane has a normal appearance in most cases. This is indicative of a matured 
or inactive focus of otosclerotic bone. Option B - A case of CSOM will have a perforated tympanic membrane. Option C - Otosclerosis with an active focus will show the Schwartze sign. Option D - In the case of otitis media with effusion the tympanic membrane is often dull and 
opaque with loss of light reflex.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 20-year-old female patient presents with features of bilateral conductive hearing loss, not 
associated with tinnitus. The following image shows the otoscopic findings of her tympanic 
membranes. What is this sign called?
questions.explanation:
The otoscopic picture of both the tympanic membranes shows the Schwartze sign. This finding 
along with the history of bilateral conductive deafness is seen in active otosclerosis. A reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). 
This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. The tympanic membrane is quite normal and mobile. Option A: Rising sun sign is seen in glomus tumor. Option C: Setting sun sign is an eye sign seen in hydrocephalus. Option D: Cartwheel appearance is seen in acute suppurative otitis media.

questions.question:
Question 12: An ENT senior resident posted in a remote village comes across a patient in whom he 
suspects otosclerosis. Which of the following tests can be used if he wants to clinically 
confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Gelle’s is a tuning fork test done to clinically confirm otosclerosis in the olden days. It is based on the fact that in a normal ear if pressure is increased in the external ear the stapes 
footplate will get medialized and will stop conducting sound. But, in an ear with otosclerosis of 
the footplate, there will be no movements and the patient will continue to hear the sound. Thus, 
Gelle’s test is considered positive in normal persons and in those with sensorineural hearing loss. 
It is negative when the ossicular chain is fixed or disconnected. Stenger’s test is done to rule out malingering. Schwabach is a tuning fork test that compares the bone conduction of the patient with that of the 
examiner. Rinne’s is a tuning fork test that compares bone conduction with air conduction.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following symptoms is not included in the triad of Van der Hoeve syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Icterus is not included in the triad of Van der Hoeve syndrome The triad of symptoms is called Van der Hoeve syndrome: 164 
Sold by @itachibot • Osteogenesis imperfecta • Otosclerosis • Blue sclera

questions.question:
Question 14: A 25-year-old woman with a family history of hearing loss in her mother developed a hearing 
problem during pregnancy. Hearing loss is bilateral and progressive. Which of the following 
is the single best investigation to establish a diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of otosclerosis and the single best investigation to 
diagnose otosclerosis is impedance audiometry. Option B- In pure tone audiometry (PTA), Carhart's notch with an air-bone gap indicates 
otosclerosis. Option C- MRI is usually not done. HRCT is the preferred imaging modality for otosclerosis. Option D- Schwabach’s test is a tuning fork test that shows conductive hearing loss.

questions.question: Question 15: Carhart’s notch typically dips at which of the following frequencies?

options.a: 4000 Hz in both BC and AC

questions.explanation:
Carhart's notch typically dips at 2000 Hz in bone conduction. Pure tone audiometry in otosclerosis: • Air conduction is poor & worse for lower frequencies. • Bone conduction is normal. • There is a large air-bone gap • In some cases, there is a dip in the bone conduction curve. It is different at different frequencies 
but the maximum dip is at 2000 Hz and is called Carhart’s notch. 165 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Boiler’s notch is a similar dip in BC and AC curve but at 4000 Hz seen in noise-induced 
hearing loss.

questions.question:
Question 16: An elderly woman with a history of otosclerosis has now come with worsening deafness. She 
attained menopause 1 year ago. What would be the most likely report if impedance 
audiometry was done for her?

options.b: Ad graph with increased stapedial reflex
options.c: As graph with loss of stapedial reflex
options.d: As graph with increased stapedial reflex

questions.explanation:
The above case is suggestive of a long-standing case of otosclerosis and impedance audiometry 
will show As graph and loss of stapedial reflex as a result of fixation of ossicles. Impedance audiometer measures 2 parameters in the middle ear: • Tympanogram - Type As is seen in otosclerosis due to decreased compliance at or near ambient 
air pressure • Stapedial reflex - Stapedial reflex is lost due to immobile ossicles.

questions.question:
Question 17: A patient was diagnosed with otosclerosis and Schwartze’s sign was positive on otoscopy. 
How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
Sodium fluoride is used in the medical management of otosclerosis. This is an active case of 
otosclerosis evidenced by Schwartze’s sign and in an active case of otosclerosis medical 
management is preferred. Surgery is contraindicated if Schwartze’s sign is positive. Schwartze sign - A reddish hue is seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane. This 
is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. In an active case of otosclerosis, medical management with Sodium fluoride (NaF) is preferred 
because NaF hastens the maturity of active focus in otosclerosis. It acts by inhibiting the 
osteoclasts and decreasing the proteolytic enzymes. 166 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: A 25-year-old woman presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss. On 
examination, the tympanic membrane is normal and the audiogram shows bilateral 
conductive deafness. Impedance audiometry shows As type of curve and acoustic reflexes are 
absent. Which of the following treatment options is not used in patients with the above 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario of bilateral progressive conductive deafness with As type of 
tympanogram and absent acoustic reflexes is suggestive of otosclerosis. Gentamicin is not used in 
the management of otosclerosis. Medical management includes the use of sodium fluoride and bisphosphonates in active cases. Surgical management includes stapedectomy and stapedotomy, though the latter is preferred due 
to decreased risk of fistula formation. Hearing aids may be used as an alternative to surgery.

questions.question:
Question 19: A primipara is being evaluated for hearing impairment which had worsened during her 
pregnancy. Rinne’s test is negative in both the ears and Weber’s lateralized to the right side. 
On otoscopy, tympanic membranes appear normal. Audiometry shows a dip in BC at 2000 
Hz. What is the treatment of choice for the above condition?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of otosclerosis and the treatment of choice for 
otosclerosis is stapedotomy. Stapedotomy is the excision of the superstructure of stapes and drilling a hole in the footplate 
& placing a piston in the hole. This is the treatment of choice. Stapedectomy is the excision of the entire stapes (superstructure + footplate) and placing a piston 
in its place. It is outdated. NaF is used in an active case of otosclerosis to hasten maturation. Note: • Both stapedectomy and stapedotomy have been described for the treatment of otosclerosis. Even 
in the stapedectomy procedure, stapedotomy (drilling) has been practiced. Hence stapedotomy is 
preferred over stapedectomy and is considered the treatment of choice. • In the above case since Rinne’s test is negative on both ears, it indicates bilateral conductive 
deafness. Weber’s test will lateralize to the ear with greater conductive loss.

questions.question:
Question 20: You are assisting in a stapedotomy procedure for a patient with otosclerosis. After 
appropriate dissection, where will you place the piston?
questions.explanation:
The piston is placed between the incus and oval window. Stapedotomy is done to bypass the immobile stapes using a piston which will take over the 
function of conducting sound. For this reason, the piston replaces the removed stapes 
superstructure. 167 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 21: You are an ENT surgeon and the following are few patients with otosclerosis. For which of the 
following patients will you advise stapedotomy?
questions.explanation:
A stapedotomy will be indicated for patients 4 and 5 as bronchial asthma and diabetes without 
schwartze sign are not contraindications for the procedure. Contraindications for Stapedotomy: • Only hearing ear • Positive Schwartze sign • Otitis externa • Meniere’s disease: can damage the inner ear while drilling a hole in the footplate • Young children • Professional athletes, pilots, construction workers, and divers: Sudden changes in pressure can 
displace the piston and cause vertigo. • Those who work in noisy surroundings: Surgery makes them more vulnerable to noise-induced 
hearing loss.

questions.question:
Question 22: An ENT surgeon has referred a patient with otosclerosis posted for stapedotomy to your 
anesthesia OPD. She has no known co-morbidities. Which of the following techniques will 
you recommend for the above patient?
questions.explanation:
Stapedotomy is preferred to be done under local anesthesia because - • Immediate on-table improvement of hearing can be assessed • Damage to the inner ear can be assessed by the patient’s symptoms of vertigo/ nystagmus • Damage to the facial nerve can be checked. 168 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 23: In a patient with otosclerosis who underwent stapedotomy, which of the following 
complications is least likely?
questions.explanation: Cholesteatoma is not a complication of stapedotomy. Complications of stapedotomy: • Sensorineural hearing loss • Injury to the facial nerve • Floating/ submerged footplate • Endolymph gush due to damage to the inner ear • Dislodgement of piston • Post-op vertigo • Dead ear.

questions.question:
Question 24: In Lempert’s fenestration, an alternative window is created in which of the following 
structures?
questions.explanation:
Lempert’s fenestration, an alternative window is created in the lateral semicircular canal to 
function for the obliterated oval window. Lempert’s fenestration operation for otosclerosis is outdated now. It has the disadvantage of a 
postoperative mastoid cavity and an inherent hearing loss of 25 dB which cannot be corrected. 169 
Sold by @itachibot Meniere’s Disease
